intro: Rubus sprengelii var. flaccidus, commonly known as the soft-stemmed blackberry, is a shrub native to the Pacific Northwest of North America. It is characterized by its trailing or prostrate growth habit and produces small, dark purple to black berries. The plant has compound leaves with three to five leaflets, and its flowers are typically white or pale pink. It thrives in moist, shaded environments and is often found in woodlands and along stream banks. The berries are edible but have a tart flavor, making them suitable for jams and preserves.
